Title: Step Pyramid of Djoser
Notes: 15 gates, white limestone casing

Title: Unfinished Step Pyramid of Sekhemhet
Notes: niched facade, unfinished, left with rough exterior no smoothed limestone, (Verner mentions limestone casing) , "probably intended to rise about 70 m (230 ft), in seven steps - higher than Djoser's." (Lehner, 94)

Title: Unfinished Pyramid
Notes: debate over whether this is Pyramid of Nebka

Title: Layer Pyramid
Notes: began as step pyramid

Title: Meidum Pyramid
Notes: limestone casing, causeway 200m, Cult Pyramid - 26 m, 75 degree angle (Verner)

Title: Bent Pyramid
Notes: limestone casing, Cult Pyramid - 52 m side, 44 degree angle, 26 m height

Title: Red Pyramid
Notes: red granite false door, no Cult Pyramid, causeway not completed

Title: Pyramid of Khufu
Notes: Cult Pyramid - 21.75m (base), 51 degree angle, 13.80 m height, limestone core and casing, likely moves to Giza for the space to build a large pyramid where there was a supply of limestone (Verner) extensive building - king chamber, queen chamber, mortuary and valley temple, boat pits

Relationship to King: Wife of Sneferu, Wife of Khufu
Title: Pyramid G 1-a
Notes: core of limestone, includes temple, chapel, boat pit

Title: Pyramid G 1-b
Notes: Queen unknown, similar to GI-a

Title: Pyramid G 1-c
Notes: casing unfinished, no boat pit, includes temple

Title: Pyramid of Djedefre
Notes: limestone casing, red granite casing on lower areas, because of the Rocky Hill the Pyramid was built on, while lower in height than the Pyramid of Khufu, Djedefre's pyramid surpassed the top of Khufu's Pyramid. (Verner, 161) Complex built in haste and parts remained unfinsihed likely due to King's "early death" (Verner 165) Cult Pyramid - 10.5 m base, 65 degree angle

Title: Pyramid of Khafre
Notes: bottom course, lower levels of casing made of red granite, then limestone casing, core of pyramid less carefully constructed than Khufu's pyramid, two entrances (indicate modification of plans), red granite sarcophagus, mortuary temple and boat pits outside it, valley temple, seems lot of use of red granite in this complex

Title: Pyramid of Menkaure
Notes: bottom courses made of red granite casing, then limestone casing, burial chamber N-S in contrast to Khufu and Khafre, likely carried out as addition (technically demanding) made of red granite (Verner 191), portcullis likely unfinished before King died. Mortuary temple completed with mudbrick casing by successor as likely is the causeway. No boat pits, no cemetary for relatives or high officials. Questions over length of reign, red granite casing maybe used to make up for smaller size, but this unfinsihed (Verner, 200)

Relationship to King: Wife of Menkaure, Daughter of Khafre
Title: Pyramid G 111-a
Notes: originally intended as cult pyramid, true pyramid with casing, limestone and bottom courses of red granite casing, mortuary temple

Title: Pyramid G 111-b
Notes: four step core, built with limestone, not cased, small mudbrick temple

Title: Pyramid G 111-c
Notes: four step core, built with limestone, not cased

Title: Mastaba of Shepseskaf
Notes: domed roof, granite base, limestone casing, causeway built to 3m, mortuary temple (granite, expanded with mudbrick), move away from Giza - space reasons? Shepsekaf also responsible for finishing Menkaure's pyramid and probably starting to build tomb for Kentkaus (Verner 205)

Relationship to King: Royal Mother (likely of Shepseskaf and Userkaf), diagreement over whether she ruled herself as regent or not (Verner 210)
Title: Pyramid of Khentkaus I
Notes: black granite, red grainite, limestone pieces found - Verner's dimensions (base - 41.85 x 43.35 m, height - 8.83 - 9.9, upper step mastaba - length 37.3 x width 35.3 x height 8.31 m), limestone casing. Boat pit. Diagreement - truncated pyramid? dating?

Title: Pyramid of Userkaf
Notes: cased with white limestone. new location of mortuary temple (southern side of pyramid), collossal statue of Userkaf in temple, Cult Pyramid - base 20.96, height 14, angle 59 degrees

Relationship to King: Wife of Userkaf, Mother of Sahure
Title: Pyramid of Neferhetepes
Notes: one of largest pyramids built for queen, white limestone casing

Title: Pyramid of Sahure
Notes: limestone casing, limestone core, "milestone in the development of royal tombs during the Old Kingdom" (Verner, 223) "new complex introduced under Sahure then became a standard" (Verner, 224), decline in quality of core material but not casing or other parts of complex, increase in "number and capacity of storage rooms" (224) different stones used in rooms of complex

Title: Pyramid of Neferirkare
Notes: step angle, 77 degrees, 72 m planned,  turned into true period from step pyramid, casing not added, height for true pyramid unknown, Verner says that successor Niuserre had to work on finishing this pyramid, as it was not complete at king's death.  But that the casing "was not completed, and they valley temple and causeway were also never built" (2001: 297) limestone casing not completed, Niuserre undertook further "construction of the temple, using mainly mudbricks and wood" (Verner, 239) CUlt Pyramid not constructed, 2m perimeter wall built of mudnrick with gates, two wooden funerary boats

Relationship to King: Wife of Neferirkare, Mother of Neferefre and Niuserre
Title: Pyramid of Khentkaus II
Notes: limestone core and casing, simple underground, "partly built after his death by Neferefre for the 'king's mother Khentkawes" had title "Mother of Two Kings of Upper and Lower Egypt" (Verner 240) temple built during Niuserre's reign

Title: Pyramid of Neferefre
Notes: pyramid unfinished became mastaba with gravel roof terrace, limestone casing blocks, Niuserre builds temple with mudbrick (Verner 247)

Title: Pyramid of Niuserre
Notes: white limestone casing. Niuserre finished pyramids of Neferirkare and Khentkawes, Neferere. There is a cult pyramid and mortuary temple, new temple innovations (Eckbau structures), red granite obelisk, and lion statue

Title: Lepsius 24
Notes: pyramid, mortuary temple and small cult pyramid ("earliest known instance of a cult pyramid in the pyramid complex of a queen" (Verner 259), limestone casing

Title: Lepsius 29 / Headless Pyramid
Notes: debate over owner of Pyramid, Merikare? Menkauhor? - Sullivan used estimated height of 32 m based on height of Khendjer pyramid, with a similar base size

Title: Pyramid of Djedkare-Isesi
Notes: white limestone casing, core material (small, irregular pieces of limestone rather than large blocks of local limestone), basalt paving replaced by alabaster (Verner 254)

Relationship to King: Wife to Djedkare, Mother to Unas?, May have ruled as regent queen while her son was young
Title: Pyramid of Setibhor
Notes: Verner for dimensions, pyramid, cult pyramid, mortuary temple - temple unusual, different from past queens (Verner 270), "The size, structure, and originality of the complex all indicate that Djedkare's consort Setibhor was someone of high social standing. According to Klaus Baer (1920-87), the demonstrable improvements and reworkings of some of the reliefs prove that the queen herself might have ruled for a time after the death of her husband Djedkare and before the coronation of (their son?)." (Verner 270) Show "growing role played by queens, and especially by the queen mothers, in the turbulent political situation of the times." (Verner 270)

Title: Pyramid of Unas
Notes: fine white limestone casing , red granite papyrus columns, "Despite the fact that Unas's pyramid is one of the smallest built in the Old Kingdom, possibly because of the king's limited resources, it represents a milestone in the development of the royal tomb: on the walls of its underground chambers first appeared the inscriptions known as Pyramid Texts." (Verner 272). pair of boat pits, core - lower quality limestone, casing - high quality limestone. increased amount of storage capacity in mortuary temple (Verner 276), small cult pyramid (base 11.5m, angle 63),

Title: Pyramid of Teti
Notes: enclosure walls made of limestone, satellite pyramid 16 m, Cult Pyramid - 15.6 heigh, 15.7 base, angle 63 (Verner 281), built of small blocks of limestone, fine limestone casing,

Title: Pyramid of Sesheshet I
Notes: built near mastabas of Unas's wives Nebet and Khenut, "the angle of 51 would be more typical of the king's rather than the queen's pyramid." (Verner 288)

Title: Pyramid of Khuit II
Notes: core - small pieces of local limestone, fine white limestone casing, mortuary temple

Relationship to King: Wife of Teti, Mother of Pepy I
Title: Pyramid of Iput I
Notes: core of local limestone, cased with white limestone, originally built as mastaba then turned into Pyramid, likely during reign of Pepy I (Verner, 287) small chapel, no cult pyramid

Title: Pyramid of Pepy I
Notes: cased with fine white limestone, "constructed in the same way as others since Djedkare's pyramid, by using small pieces of limestone bound together with clay motar." (Verner 289) mortuary temple similar to Teti, modification during reign of Merenre I (Verner 291) Cult Pyramid 15.75 m long.  large number of Queen's Pyramids (9) "seems to reflect the changing social conditions in the country at that time. The king very probably tried to stregnthen his weakened position through political marraiges with women from influential families from different parts of Egypt." (Verner 292) Pyramids of the queens "look similar" (292)

Title: Pyramid of Inenek Inti
Notes: built first, "hereditary princess and vizier," three step core with small pieces of local limestone, fine white limestone casing, entrance chapel, mortuary temple, small cult pyramid (6.5 height, 128 base from Sullivan), offering tables "attest to the worship of the queen long after her death" (Verner 294)

Title: Pyramid of Nebuwenet
Notes: three step core, limestone, chapel built of mudbrick, faced with limestone, mortuary temple - small, limestone

Relationship to King: Wife of Pepy I, Mother of Merenre
Title: Pyramid of Ankhnespepy I
Notes: unknown

Relationship to King: Wife of Pepy I and Merenre, Mother and Queen Regent for Pepy II
Title: Pyramid of Ankhnespepy II
Notes: largest pyramid for Pepy I's queens, walls of chamber decorated with Pyramid texts, limestone casing, mortuary temple, red granite obelisk - first occurance in complex of queen, offering tables

Title: The Pyramid "de l'Ouest"
Notes: three step core of local limestone, fine white limestone casing, substructure and mortuary temple slightly different - location of burial chamber, and temple made of mudbrick with many small rooms,

Relationship to King: Daughter of Pepy I, Wife of Pepy II, Vizier
Title: Pyramid of Meretities II
Notes: fragments of wooden box with pyramid text passages, mortuary temple cased with limestone

Relationship to King: Mother of Netjerykhethor (a non-ruling Royal) - "the eldest king's son of his body"
Title: Pyramid of Mehaa
Notes: dimensions unknown, but likely similar to Nebuwenet

Title: Pyramid of Behenu
Notes: dimensions from Verner - pyramid larger than Mehaa's (greater importance, gragments of Pyramid Texts mentioning her, mortuary temple

Title: Pyramid of Sebutet?
Notes: dimensions unknown

Title: Pyramid of Nedjeftet?
Notes: dimensions unknown

Relationship to King: Wife of Pepy II, Mother to Neferkare, Daughter of Merenre
Title: Pyramid of Ankhnespepy III
Notes: fine limestone casing, pyramid similar to Udjebten (wife of Pepy II), may have been built during same time, no entrance chapel, "fragments of a wooden box inscribed with the Pyramid Texts were found in the chamber... shows that the Pyramid Texts could occur on movable objects... also attests to the democratization of religious ideas and burial customs" (Verner 297), mortuary temple, offering hall, small cult pyramid (3.1 m long)

Title: Pyramid of Merenre
Notes: cased with fine limestone, causeway 200m long, enclosure walls made of mudbrick, valuable materials ("red granite from Aswan, calcite alabaster from Hatnub, and dark grey-wacke from the quarries in Ibhat" (Verner 300), pyramid texts

Title: Pyramid of Pepy II
Notes: six step core built of small rough cut local limestone blocks bound with clay, fine white limestone casing, unusual band of limestone likely built after Pepy II's death, Pyramid texts, mortuary temple,  small cult pyramid

Relationship to King: Wife of Pepy II, Mother of Merenre II, Sister of Merenre
Title: Pyramid of Neith
Notes: satellite pyramid 5.25 m sq (Sullivan), mortuary temple, two limestone obelisks, three step core, same materials as king's pyramid, similar substructure to queens of Pepy I, sixteen wooden models of boats lying in shallow pit discovered

Title: Pyramid of Iput II
Notes: very similar to Queen Neith but smaller with poorer quality burial equipment, sarcophagus of Queen AnkhnesPepy III found in storeroom (consort of Pepy II and mother of Neferkare Neby who ruled in 8th Dynasty)

Title: Pyramid of Wedjebten
Notes: pyramidion plated with finest gold, pyramid texts in burial chamber, simply decorated mortuary temple, offering table

Pyramid Owner: Below are Kings who ruled between Pepy II and Ibi (without known monuments), their length of reign is uncertain

Title: Pyramid of Ibi
Notes: casing not put in place, chapel made of mudbrick, core made of "small stones," (Lehner); Sullivan estimates 21m high, but one could argue that it was based on Ankhesenpepy II's pyramid (30m).

Pyramid Owner: Below are Kings who ruled after Ibi (without certainty on their monuments), their length of reign is uncertain

Title: Pyramid of Neferkauhor?
Notes: no archaeological evidence of a pyramid, but inscriptional evidence (overseer of pyramid town), cf. Papazian, 420

Title: Pyramid of Demedjibtawj?
Notes: no archaeological evidence of a pyramid, but inscriptional evidence (overseer of pyramid town), cf. Papazian, 420

Title: Pyramid of Ity?
Notes: no archaeological evidence of a pyramid, but inscriptional evidence (pyramid name), cf. Papazian, 420.
